channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Science That Makes Baseball Mud ‘Magical’
item.description: Scientists dug up the real dirt on the substance applied to all the baseballs used in the major leagues.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:credit: Elsa/Getty Images
item.media:description: Daniel Hudson of the Los Angeles Dodgers during Game 4 of the World Series last week. Mud is applied to new baseballs because they are glossy and slippery, making them difficult for pitchers to grip.

item.title: Where There’s Joy in a Terror Bird
item.description: In Colombia, a fossil-collecting rancher has found a giant, flightless killer from 13 million years ago — and a missing link to the region’s evolutionary history.
item.dc:creator: Jennie Erin Smith and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: César Perdomo, a rancher and fossil hunter in Colombia’s Tatacoa Desert, with a terror bird fossil. Until his find, little was known about how these carnivores spread across the Americas millions of years ago.

item.title: Follow Your Nose to the Next Museum Exhibit
item.description: Museums are adding scents as another tool for communicating information about science and other subjects in their exhibits.
item.dc:creator: Becky Ferreira
item.media:credit: Heather Ainsworth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Experiencing 18th century nutmeg at the “Sensorium,” an exhibit of scents, glass and perfumery at the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y.

item.title: Diving to Drink a 19th-Century Shipwreck’s Treasure
item.description: A team recently dived deep beneath Lake Huron hoping to harvest grain that may one day be distilled into whiskey with a flavor forgotten to history.
item.dc:creator: Cara Giaimo

item.title: Can Axions Save the Universe?
item.description: The hunt for dark matter is shifting from particles to waves named after a laundry detergent.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye and Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: John P. Dessereau

item.title: Two Black Holes are Giving the Cosmos a Fright
item.description: The ghosts of stars are up to their usual mischief.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Andrew Beardmore (Univ. of Leicester) and NASA/Swift

item.title: Some Geologists Argue Earth Has Fewer Than Seven Continents
item.description: Recent earth science developments suggest that how we count our planet’s largest land masses is less clear than we learned in school.
item.dc:creator: Matt Kaplan

item.title: If You Think You Can Hold a Grudge, Consider the Crow
item.description: The brainy birds carry big chips on their shoulders, scientists say. And some people who become subjects of their ire may be victims of mistaken identity.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Alana Paterson
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Marzluff believes a crow can hold a grudge for 17 years.

item.title: The Rebellious Scientist Who Made Kamala Harris
item.description: The presidential candidate’s mother, Shyamala Gopalan Harris, was a breast cancer researcher whose egalitarian politics often bucked a patriarchal lab culture.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Kamala Harris campaign, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kamala Harris with her mother, Shyamala Gopalan Harris, in 2007, during a Chinese New Year Parade.

item.title: Trump’s Embrace of RFK Jr. Puts Fluoride, Vaccines and Obamacare on the Agenda
item.description: Donald Trump’s pledge to let Robert F. Kennedy Jr. “go wild on health” has put three issues on the agenda in the final days of the 2024 campaign.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

item.title: A Record Number of States Are in Drought
item.description: Little rain has fallen since Hurricane Helene dropped huge amounts across the Southeast.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney and Mira Rojanasakul

item.title: Cost of Mpox Shot Deters Americans at Risk, Critics Say
item.description: The epidemic in Africa continues to grow, prompting fears of another outbreak in the U.S. But the vaccine is no longer free, and vulnerable people are going without.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times

item.title: Richard A. Cash, Who Saved Millions From Dehydration, Dies at 83
item.description: He worked alongside another doctor to show that a simple rehydration therapy could check the ravages of cholera and other diarrhea-inducing diseases.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: COP16 Talks in Colombia Adopt a Novel Way to Pay for Conservation
item.description: Delegates at the U.N. talks created a system that would compensate countries for the use of genetic information but failed to make headway on a broader funding commitment.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:credit: Gabriel Aponte/Getty Images
item.media:description: The talks, sponsored by the United Nations, were held in Cali, Colombia.

item.title: In Mexico, Archaeologists Spot a Maya City Behind a Wall of Trees
item.description: A city with temple pyramids not far from the road and a site with a Maya complex built alongside a sinkhole lend to evidence that the Maya civilization was even more sprawling than known.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Luke Auld-Thomas Et Al, via Reuters
item.media:description: In this lidar image released by Cambridge University Press, what archaeologists in Mexico say is a newly discovered lost Maya city, which they named Valeriana, is hidden deep in the southern jungle of Campeche, Mexico.

item.title: What Caused Spain’s Flash Flooding?
item.description: The region is no stranger to storms like those that caused this week’s deluges. But global warming helps them pack a bigger punch, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Alberto Saiz/Associated Press
item.media:description: A pileup of cars in Valencia, Spain, on Wednesday, after catastrophic rains.

item.title: From AI to Musk’s Brain Chip, the F.D.A.’s Device Unit Faces Rapid Change
item.description: The new director overseeing medical devices will confront criticisms about hasty approvals as she ushers in revolutionary technology.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times
item.media:description: A brain-computer implant device that has allowed its user, Casey Harrell of California, who has ALS, to be able to speak with the assistance of an A.I.-powered computer voice. Blackrock Neurotech made the device for research purposes.

item.title: 1 in 4 Child Deaths After E.R. Visits Are Preventable, Study Finds
item.description: If every emergency room in the United States were fully prepared to treat children, thousands of lives would be saved and the cost would be $11.84 or less per child, researchers found.
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Data from 4,840 emergency rooms across the United States found that 842 of them — less than one-fifth — were considered well-prepared for pediatric emergencies.

item.title: Sugar Rationing Lowered Diabetes and Hypertension in British Children
item.description: British data shows that children conceived and born during a period of sugar rationing were less likely to develop diabetes or high blood pressure later in life.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Monty Fresco/Topical Press Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Children waiting for a sweetshop to open during a pause in sweets rationing in Britain in 1949.

item.title: How a Second Trump Term Could Recast Public Health
item.description: Breaking up the C.D.C., moving funds from the N.I.H. — conservatives have floated changes should Mr. Trump regain office.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. appearing with Donald Trump at a campaign rally in Duluth, Ga., this month. Mr. Trump’s embrace of his vaccine skepticism suggests there will be significant changes to the nation’s public health priorities should Mr. Trump regain the presidency.

item.title: Ozempic and Wegovy Ease Knee Osteoarthritis Pain in Large Study
item.description: A large trial showed that semaglutide, sold as Ozempic for diabetes and as Wegovy for obesity, was better than any current medications in alleviating symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: M. Scott Brauer for The New York Times
item.media:description: A study of 407 people with obesity and knee osteoarthritis found those who got semaglutide had an average reduction of 41.7 points on a 100-point scale while those who got the placebo had a reduction of 27.5 points.

item.title: Does Kamala Harris Back Free Health Care for Illegal Immigrants?
item.description: Donald Trump and other Republicans have said repeatedly that she does. Her history on the issue is complicated.
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Since Vice President Kamala Harris announced her candidacy for president this year, her campaign has been evasive on the issue of medical coverage for undocumented immigrants.

item.title: Heart-Valve Patients Should Have Earlier Surgery, Study Suggests
item.description: The results of a new clinical trial have overturned the “wait and see” approach that cardiologists have long favored for symptom-free patients.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Zephyr/Science Source
item.media:description: A CT scan of a 64-year-old patient with heart failure showing calcification of the aortic valve, bright white, in center, which can lead to aortic valve stenosis.

item.title: Fossil Reveals Oldest Known Tadpole That Grew to the Size of a Hot Dog
item.description: A 161 million-year-old fossil, linked to a line of extinct frog-like amphibians, is the oldest tadpole ever found.
item.dc:creator: Asher Elbein

item.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX, Already a Leader in Satellites, Gets Into the Spy Game
item.description: The Pentagon needs what the company offers to compete with China even as it frets over its potential for dominance and the billionaire’s global interests.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying a spy satellite launching from Vandenberg Space Force Base in Lompoc, Calif., in 2022.

item.title: Harris Took Steady Approach to Space as Chair of White House Council
item.description: As chair of the White House’s National Space Council, the vice president largely emphasized continuity with policies set by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang and Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ting Shen
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris during a visit to the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., in 2021.

item.title: Clean Energy Is Booming in the U.S. The Election Could Change That.
item.description: Trump has suggested he would dismantle the Inflation Reduction Act, which has reshaped America’s energy landscape. It won’t be easy.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Kristian Thacker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A battery manufacturing plant under construction at the site of a former steel mill in Weirton, W.Va.

item.title: Was Stone-Age Scandinavia Struck by Plague?
item.description: New research by geneticists hints at the deadly work of Yersinia pestis 5,000 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz

item.title: Can John Green Make You Care About Tuberculosis?
item.description: With a forthcoming nonfiction book and an online army of Nerdfighters, the young-adult author aims to eliminate an entirely curable global scourge.
item.dc:creator: Maddie Bender
item.media:credit: Lee Klafczynski for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Green, the best selling author and YouTuber, wants to bridge an “empathy gap” for tuberculosis, which disproportionately affects people in sub-Saharan Africa, Eastern Europe and Asia.

item.title: Why Is Harris So Passionate About Abortion Rights? Her Past Work Holds Clues.
item.description: For a politician who has been criticized for shifting positions on some issues, this is an area where she has shown unwavering conviction.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight and Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris on the campaign trail in Marietta, Ga., last month. She has made abortion rights a centerpiece of her bid for the presidency.

item.title: This Toad Is So Tiny That They Call It a Flea
item.description: A “toadlet” in Brazil is the second-smallest vertebrate known to exist on the planet.
item.dc:creator: Sofia Quaglia
